Key Arguments: The legislation represents a significant overreach by the government.
It is inconsistent with international human rights agreements that Australia is a signatory to.
The bill grants excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without accountability or transparency.
Digital providers could police speech and shut down dissent without accountability.
The bill could be used to suppress free discussion and dissenting voices.
The definition of 'harm' used in the bill is ideologically driven.
Historical examples, such as Nazi Germany, are cited as cautionary tales of government overreach.
Government content is exempt from scrutiny, likening the situation to authoritarian regimes.
The bill infringes on privacy by allowing ACMA to demand private information.
There is insufficient accountability for misuse and abuse of censorship powers.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessively severe and could stifle free speech.
Notable Quotes: No government now or in the future should wield this much say on its citizens.
The Bill gives power to unelected bureaucrats with no accountability in public place and no transparency of what they have chosen as their truth.
This is no different than North Korea and Chinese regimes.
The severity of penalties for failing to comply are beyond belief and will cause a high level of loss of freedom of speech by fear of penalties.
